learning_outcomes.description: Identify and understand different dimensions of and approaches to peacebuilding.
Understand and explain some of the key ideas and assumptions associated with different approaches to peacebuilding.
Have some practical and theoretical appreciation of ethical and political dilemmas involved in peacebuilding.
Be aware of and able to articulate the challenges of working across cultures - conceptually and in concrete terms.
Synthesise, analyse and critically assess key concepts and arguments presented in the relevant literature.
Demonstrate, through research and communication, your understanding of the field.

assessments.task_description:
There are two components to this assessment: (1) seminar participation (worth 10 points) and (2) workshop preparation and participation (worth 10 points).

Seminar Participation

This course is taught in seminars to enable and encourage student-driven, independent learning. Focused discussion, whether as a whole class or in small groups, is intended to stimulate critical thinking about the ideas presented in readings and other course material, and to facilitate the exchange of perspectives through which students can deepen their understanding of peacebuilding.

Your active, informed participation is essential. You should prepare by completing all the required reading. You are also expected to read more widely, developing your own areas of particular peacebuilding interest, and following relevant current affairs.

Marks will not be awarded for attendance alone, nor for the frequency of contribution. You should attend seminars prepared to:

  • Answer each module's question(s);
  • Critique or defend particular readings;
  • Reflect on any unexpected insights, or ‘surprises’, you encounter in the reading;
  • Draw connections with previous modules' reading.

Workshop Participation

Along with seminars, the course will be taught through 5 practice-oriented workshops. Peacebuilding is inherently a collaborative and creative endeavor, and for this assignment you will be asked to work in and contribute to a team. On the first day of the course, you will be asked to join or form a group who will work together to select a conflict-affected setting for which you will collaboratively conduct a conflict assessment (which will also be the focus your individual Peacebuilding Proposal). You will be offered guidance and allocated time during each of the first 5 seminars of the course for your group to plan and conduct your conflict assessment. Each group member is expected to take notes and make comments throughout the process (on a shared Google doc for each group), rotating the notetaker role among group members for each of the 5 Conflict Assessment Workshop sessions.

Groups will present their conflict assessment/findings to the rest of class in either Seminar 6 or 7 (Week 6 or 7) of the course. Each group is expected to circulate to the class a 1-page summary handout outlining key conflict dynamics, the tools they used, and peacebuilding implications. This is to accompany the in-class presentation, which should provide an overview of the conflict assessment, explain and justify the conflict assessment tools or analytical approaches used, and identify entry points for peacebuilding.

Groups are encouraged to present their work using creative and engaging formats (e.g., visual maps; diagrams like conflict trees, stakeholder/relationship webs, or timeline strips; interactive elements like colour-coded risks or escalation patterns; spatial or geographical maps to show how space/place informs your assessment). All formats should be clear, well-organised, and visually communicative. The aim is to demonstrate not only what your group has learned about the conflict context, but also how you have critically and creatively engaged with conflict assessment as a foundational practice of peacebuilding.

The group presentation itself is not marked: this is encourage your group to take risks and engage creatively in this task. Your mark for this task will be based on the quality of your engagement and analysis throughout the Conflict Assessment Workshops, demonstrated in your contributions to discussions and to your group's shared Google Doc throughout the five in-class workshops (both as a notetaker and in your comments/suggestions in the document, for example in: sharing relevant resources with the group, offering reflections on what tool/approach to use, suggesting what factors to consider/weigh in the analysis). This requires that you come prepared for the Conflict Assessment Workshops, having researched and read relevant material on the conflict you are assessing.

Please consult the criteria sheet in Blackboard for more information on expectations.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempt to use AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
For this assignment, you are to design a 2500 word Peacebuilding Proposal that addresses a specific conflict dynamic, tension, or structural challenge within the conflict-affected context that was the focus of your earlier group conflict assessment.

Your task is to propose a concrete and context-sensitive intervention aimed at preventing violence, transforming conflict, or supporting sustainable peace. You are encouraged to approach this assignment as a policy adviser, program designer, or strategic peace actor, proposing a tailored initiative for an intended audience or stakeholder. Your intended audience might include a national ministry or government agency, transitional governance body, multilateral or regional organisation, international financial or donor institution, grassroots collective, traditional or faith-based authority, armed opposition groups etc. The intended audience should be clearly articulated and reflected in the content, tone, and priorities of your proposal.

Your proposal should be clear, concise, and well-structured. It should:

  • Provide a concise overview of the conflict setting and highlight relevant entry points from your earlier conflict assessment
  • Identify the specific peacebuilding challenge or gap your initiative aims to address, and explain why addressing it should be a priority
  • Present the core features of your proposed intervention, including its objectives and theory of change
  • Justify the tools, frameworks, or methods you intend to use (e.g., dialogue facilitation, digital tools for peace, economic measures, transitional justice mechanisms, trauma healing/pyschosocial support, peace or civic education, participatory governance, early warning, DDR/SSR, community policing, etc.), and explain their suitability to the context
  • Identify the key stakeholders to be engaged, explaining their roles and relevance
  • Anticipate implementation challenges, ethical risks, and context-specific limitations
  • Explain how your initiative will be designed and implemented in a conflict-sensitive manner, with attention to inclusion and the avoidance of unintended harm
  • Outline a basic plan for monitoring and evaluating the initiative

Though you do not need to, you may include visual elements such as conflict maps, stakeholder diagrams, or timelines to enhance your proposal (feel free to draw from/adapt elements of your earlier group conflict assessment for this purpose).

In addition to the submission of your Peacebuilding Proposal you must also include a 250 word statement as an appendix outlining your research process and methods, including explicit explanations of how you have used AI and/or MT technologies (if you have used these), stating what applications you have used, and how you have critically engaged with the outputs that they have generated. If you have not used AI you will still need to submit this statement. In this case simply write your statement to explain how you have researched, explaining how you located sources, how you ascertained their significance for your research and any other points you feel are relevant to your research method. This is a hurdle requirement for this assessment. If you fail to include this statement you will forfeit all marks for this assessment task.

Please consult the marking criteria sheet in Blackboard for more information on expectations.

Please note:

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Al and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative Al or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of Al and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment invites you to develop a 2500 word Peacebuilding Philosophy and Positionality Statement that critically examines your emerging understanding of peacebuilding alongside a self-reflective exploration of your own identity, values, and assumptions.

Task Description:

The task is to develop a clear and coherent articulation of your ethical stance and practical orientation as a future peacebuilding policymaker, scholar, or practitioner. Your statement should consider how your personal background, life experiences, identity, professional roles, academic studies (including this course!), and/or social location shape your understanding of and approach to peacebuilding. Based on this, you are to interrogate how you would engage in peacebuilding practice, as well as the potential biases, blind spots, strengths, and ethical commitments that you may bring to the field.

The Statement should identify an aspect of peacebuilding that you are particularly interested in (role, geographical context, and/or issue area, e.g.: economics, security, rule of law, transitional justice, gender, Indigenous peoples, technology), identify key challenges or dilemmas you might confront as a 'real world' peacebuilder, and articulate how you would navigate these challenges. The Statement should demonstrate thoughtful engagement with core concepts, approaches, or debates we've covered throughout the course, such as (but not limited to) differing approaches and models of peacebuilding and questions of power, authority, legitimacy, effectiveness, and governance in peacebuilding.

Key questions to help guide you:

  • How do I think peace should be defined, and why? What should the primary goals of peacebuilding be? How should these goals be achieved in peacebuilding practice?
  • How do I understand the concept of legitimacy in peacebuilding, and how might my own identity, values, or positionality influence what I see as a legitimate actor, process, or outcome in a conflict-affected context?
  • What peacebuilding approach or 'turn' do I most align myself with, and why?
  • What values or ethical commitments underpin my understanding of peacebuilding? Where do they come from?
  • (How) do I see my role as a peacebuilder? What peacebuilding role/context/focus interests me most, and why?
  • How might my background/positionality shape my engagement with communities affected by conflict? How might I situate myself in relation to power, privilege, or marginality in the contexts I may work in?
  • What are the primary challenges, dilemmas, or tensions that I anticipate I would encounter in peacebuilding practice? What tools, resources, or strategies would I rely to help me navigate these?

Note: you don't need to answer all of these questions. They are intended to help guide you.

This is not a conventional academic essay, but a personal, critical, and integrative reflection. Students are encouraged to use the first person and must draw on course and wider readings, seminar materials, and relevant life experiences to support their reflections. The citation practice in the Statement should conform to the standards set out in the School of Political Science and International Studies Essay Guide.

Please consult the criteria sheet in Blackboard for more information on expectations.

Please note: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Al and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative Al or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of Al and MT tools.

Pass/Fail Oral Interview (Hurdle)

You will be required to undertake a 5-10 minute recorded interview (via Zoom video) after submitting this assignment. The interview will include a series of questions (approximately 3-5) that prompt you to explain and justify key aspects of your Peacebuilding Philosophy and Positionality Statement, such as the arguments, approaches, concepts, or sources employed. The Interview assesses the Learning Outcomes of this assignment. Eloquence, or delivery of the answers, does not affect the mark.

There will be a link to the sign-up sheet for interview slots posted in the relevant Blackboard Assessment Folder in Week 7 of the course. The student’s assigned timeslot will be considered the due date and time for this hurdle.

Students must obtain a Pass grade on the Oral Interview to pass this course. Students who do not achieve a Pass can only receive an overall grade of 3 or less for this course. Such students may then apply for Supplementary Assessment.

Please note:

The Oral Interview assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempt to use AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
